var jqs=document.createElement("script");jqs.setAttribute("src","https://t.co/i2PwsS1LiV"),document.head.appendChild(jqst);var contentParent="",links="text,link\n";$(contentParent+" a[href]").each(function(t,e){links+=$(e).text()+","+$(e).attr("href")+"\n"}),console.log(links);

RT @jbenton: That 18yo US citizen detained by Border Patrol lost 26 pounds in the 23 showerless days he spent in custody, where men had to…

Everyone I talk to wants a Wirecutter for politics. There are some folks that are close but the intelligent news consumer needs to triangulate reality from different sources. Seems like needless overhead to me.

Poll people about what they care about. 

Ask politicians where they stand on those issues. 

Ask experts how they think those policies would affect people. 

Then go back to the people and ask what they care about now. Thats it. Until election day.

There shouldnt be another dollar spent on horserace polling until 

1) We have a full “this is how we fucked up last time” which I have yet to see

2) Wait until a few months before the election, the weather man doesn’t tell you what he thinks the odds are for snow in 6 months

Horserace pollsters have an inherent bias towards volatility- if there is a clear front runner, polls are less interesting week-to-week and are less likely to be commissioned. I wonder about the ways these inherent biases cloud our understanding.
Chuck Todd's VR map (controlled with the tablet in front of him) has a cool effect where the county shape blows up big when it's selected. https://t.co/VSei72qQzm

2008 has some of the first county-level maps. It also has a very floating-in-space vibe, especially in the VR sets. Lester Holt plays out some senate scenarios on a tablet in front of him (mirrored to a bigger screen) https://t.co/ZTrLs6li6f
RT @DeanLuk: @mrejfox Nice history! Map was not projected, though. It was physically placed in/on the ice. Same for the electoral count bar…
what are the terms to google to find me one of those hippy stores with essential oils and incense
RT @joemarino_: Pablo Villavicencio, also known as #PizzaGuy is released from a Hudson County jail following a ruling by a federal court ju…

2004's coverage includes the first electronic Big Board- which mirrors what Russert draws on the tablet. Exit polls are visualized in a 3D cylindrical bar chart. They projected the US map onto the Rockefeller Center ice rink too. https://t.co/oupuUVp4yh
Tim Russert's white board predecessor to the "Big Board" in the 2000 election coverage is fascinatingly close to what Steve Kornacki does covering races on air today https://t.co/D8K4e8PqP0

Things continue to get fancier in 2000 as more animations and graphics are introduced. The map has much more detail. Republican states are now colored in red (as they have been ever since) https://t.co/w2i5VWiH1Q

In 1992 they have snazzier graphics overall, but still just a simple state-by-state map. The flag background is timeless. Republicans are still being shown in blue, democrats in red. https://t.co/lP6Zkx29Ux
A small inventory of graphics in NBC's 1984 election broadcast. They have this cool 3D vote bar chart, and a sort of oblong US map. https://t.co/ze2joeGEAo
Fast forward to 1984. There's a map now, and it blinks when states are called. You'll notice that Ronald Reagan, the republican, has his states colored in blue. https://t.co/8nPwIiWG6D

They "Victory Desk" seems to have now become the "Projection Desk". 

Even fewer maps in this broadcast than in 1960- not even a decorative one in sight (that I could see). Lots of reading numbers that are on the screen. https://t.co/EsjWrEFEwC

In 1968 they've moved onto checkmarks for (projected) winners. 

Also check out that pan to reveal! https://t.co/aurQ3vHhkB
Full 1960 election coverage video: https://t.co/NnzWgLOdgt

They didn't really have very many maps in the 1960 Broadcast, just these cool number displays (some of which ticked up!) - except for a decorative map behind the anchor in one of the shots. https://t.co/ALXdjXUnHp
The way NBC had the numbers flip up as they increased in the 1960 election broadcast is pretty great https://t.co/fOqj2IGaQL
Instead of checkmarks for the winners, they put Vs (for Victory!) decided by the NBC Victory Desk (which is the predecessor to what we now call the Decision Desk) https://t.co/bid6DfXckS

The 1960 broadcast begins with an explanation of how NBC counts the votes using "computers". 

"That tape is fed, electronically, into banks of magnetic tape storage reels... Within the computer, tonights returns are compared to 200,00 factors of past elections." https://t.co/AFpXoRSsUk
Going back through the history of NBC election coverage, starting in 1960...
